From Greg Abrams review, entitled "everyone except snobbery", the next comment on the product page: "well, do you want a good (if a little" basic ") distorted sound for less than $100? This is your deal." I strongly object. You can find better distortion effects at a price of $100 or less, and even some distortion effects close to or lower than the DS-1's current price of $40. I've been playing the guitar for more than 10 years. Like many people, the pedal I first bought was the DS-1. After all, everyone is talking about them. They can be bought in any specific music store in the country. You heard that all these famous musicians are using them. In addition, DS-1 is actually quite cheap! So I robbed one like everyone else. You'll find that just because something is popular doesn't always mean it's good (see nickel, transformers, Kardashian family, etc.). So I plugged it in and didn't like it very much. Distortion is harsh, thin, artificial sound, always noisy. I have tried on both my amplifiers (my practical amplifier: solid-state fender frontman 25R and my large amplifier, B-52 at100, which is a 100W tube half stack) it is not very diverse, and I don't like the basic sound very much. I have read that the DS-1 made in Japan sounds better than the new model made in Taiwan, but in any case, the DS-1 is not a good pedal in my mind. But like many new players, I didn't know what was better. Fast forward a few years, I have bought and sold dozens of pedals. If you open your eyes, you will find that the whole world has great tones. So here are some pedals I currently have, which I like better than the DS-1. All of these are great universal distortions. It's easy to find new ones and use them in most guitar stores. At the time of writing this article, you can buy new ones for $75 or less on the good ol'amazon here. I started with "big brother" of DS-1 because I'm afraid that others think I'm a person who hates the boss (of course I'm not, I like TU-3, odb-3, MD-2, xt-2, etc.). This pedal has a better tone, not to mention two different distortion modes. The I setting is almost a higher quality DS-1, and the II setting is a brighter and richer tone. Since DS-1 is completely more popular than DS-2, you can find DS-2 on eBay at a very cheap price. A valuable pedal has unfortunately been ignored by many people. Pro Co Rat2: the pedal is very dirty. Maybe it's my personal favorite. In the past 30 years, you have heard that this box has been used in hundreds of songs. It is used by a large number of guitarists. This is a rich, full distortion that becomes slightly blurred at higher gain. I've never heard my bad voice. It's great to get a "big amplifier" sound from a small practice amplifier. It is also very suitable for pushing a large amplifier with too much clearance into the best position of super drive without turning the volume of the amplifier. A really good pedal. Ehx little big muff: big muff is another pedal you hear in hundreds of songs. It's a little fuzzy and distorted, but it must have its own range. Very large, saturated, warm. In the 1970s, it was widely used in the tone of classical rock music, and in the 1990s and later, it was used in a large number of garbage and garages. Everyone from Carlos Santana and David Gilmour to smashed pumpkin, little dinosaur and Jack White uses it. I personally recommend this small and large sleeve. Not only is its tone softer than that recently reissued in New York, it is smaller, uses an ordinary 9V adapter, and is cheaper! A great pedal. MXR distortion +: distortion + is a great first distortion that can usually be found very cheap. The advantage of distortion + is that it sounds great on any occasion, and the lack of tone knob helps to maintain its transparency, that is, you can hear the natural tone of guitar and amplifier more easily, and it won't cover your voice. Many celebrities have used it, including the great God of death Jerry Garcia, Randy Rhodes (Oz's famous guitarist) and sex pistol Band Steve Jones. DANELECTRO cm-1 cool cat metal: make sure you get cool cat metal, not metal II. It's a good pedal as well, but it's definitely more traditional metal pedal. Cool cat metal, or cm-1, is actually a very, very different pedal from most metal pedals. Basically, it's a preamplifier on the floor. It has a fully adjustable equalizer that can be adjusted into tons of volume and gain through the roof. So you can do anything from a clean enhancement (lowest gain, almost no coloring of the your tone) to a high gain metal material with the a lot of the super drive and rock tones in between. It works well with any amplifier I've tried, and you can find a lot of great sound. This is an incredibly versatile pedal, even a real bypass. Best of all, DANELECTRO seems to give way too much, so you can easily find a used or even new one for less than $30. A real hidden gem is actually cheaper than the DS-1. Joyo jf-03 crunch twist: this little guy surprised me. It is considered to be a clone of MI audio crunch box. If so, it must be a great pedal. It's essentially a Marshall pile in a box, boy, it's been successful. Huge creak, tons of volume and gain, it can really make your practice amplifier sound like a big pile of rags! It even sounds good in my modeling amplifier (few pedals can be used with my modeling amplifier, and this one is even better than the built-in Marshall simulation). You can buy a brand new one for $40, great! Speaking of Joyo, I bought some pedals and one or two pedals from Moen, another Chinese pedal manufacturer. I'm really surprised that their prices are frighteningly low (especially Moen Mo FM fuzzy moon, which honestly tells every big muff I've played). So Joyo and Moen, they have made all kinds of fluff, OD and dirt pedals that sound great. Look at them (before anyone starts to fully support a Chinese company, please remember that all pedals listed in my comments, including DS-1, are not made in the United States, let alone in the western hemisphere). I hope these suggestions will make you look forward to it. In addition, if you can't try pedals in the store, YouTube is a good place to hear demonstrations of different pedals. I should also mention that if you try to like DS-1 and it suits your needs, it will bring you more motivation. The tone is subjective. The sound of each pedal in different guitars and amplifiers is different, just because I may have different views on what you like, which doesn't matter. The main reason I post this lengthy comment is to give some information to novices. You have many options for deformable pedals. DS-1 is not the only product with reasonable price. Find something you really like and buy it. If it's the DS-1, one of the pedals I mentioned here, or anything else, it's important that it sounds right to you.

I've been playing guitar for over ten years. Like many people, one of my first purchases was the DS-1. After all, everyone talks about them, they are available at any given music store in the nation, you hear about all these famous musicians using them, plus one DS-1 is really cheap! So I busted one just like everybody else. Come find out that just because something is POPULAR, which does not always mean your BO (see: Nickelback, the Transformers film franchise, the Kardashian family, etc.). So I called and I didn't like it very much. The distortion was hard, thin, artificial, sounding and always noisy. I tried on both my amps (My practical amp: a solid state Fender Frontman 25R, and my big amp, the B-52 AT100, which is a halfstack 100th tube) was not very diverse, and the basic sound was not very similar to me. I read that the Japanese DS-1 is better in sound than the newest, made in Taiwanese models, but, anyway, the DS-1 is not a big pedal in my mind. But like many younger players, I didn't know anything at the time. It advanced a few years and I bought and sold literally dozens of pedals. There's a whole world of big tones to be discovered out there if you keep your eyes open. So here are some pedals that I currently own that I like much better than the DS-1. All of them are big distortions of general purpose, easy to find new and used in most guitar stores, and can, at the time of this writing, be bought new ones for $75 or less here on good old Amazon. With, and are rough enough to last years:Head DS-2 Turbo Distortion: To not catch any flames of people who think I am a boss hater (I certainly am not, I loved TU-3, ODB-3, MD-2, and XT-2, among others) I will start with DS-1's older brother. This pedal has a much nicer tone for it, not to mention two distinct modes of distortion. The I setting is much more DS-1 quality, the II setting is a brighter and richer tone. As the DS-1 completely overshadows the DS-2 in popularity, you can find DS-2 across the ebay for very cheap prices. A very dignified pedal, sadly neglected by many. Co-RAT2: Big dirty distortion pedal. Probably my favorite. You've heard this box used in literally hundreds if not thousands of songs in the last thirty years, it's used by just a ridiculous amount of guitarists. It is a rich and complete distortion that in higher gains it is slightly blurred. I've never heard a bad tone out of mine. It's great to get a "big amplifier" kind of sound from a little practice amplifier. It is also large to push a large amp with a lot of head space to the overloaded sweet point without having to rotate the amplification volume. An excellent pedal. The Big Muff is another pedal you've heard on hundreds of songs. It's a kind of confusion, a kind of distortion, but it definitely has its own sonic territory. Very large, saturated and hot. Used heavily in 70s for classic rock tones, also in the 90's and beyond for tons of grunge and garage. Used by everyone from Carlos Santana and David Gilmour to Smashing Pumpkins, Dinosaur Jr. and Jack White. I, personally, reccomend the Little Big Muff, not only is it a little more creamy in tone than the recent NYC reissue, its minor, uses a regular 9v adapter and its CHEAPER! A big pedal. MXR+ distortion: The distortion +is a great first distortion, and can usually be found very cheap. What is good about the Distortion +that looks great in anything, and the lack of a tone button helps to keep it a little transparent, i.e. you can more easily hear the natural tone of your guitar and amp, it does not cover the sound of your equipment. Used by some famous people, including the Greatful Deads Jerry Garcia, Randy Rhoads (Ozzy's famous guitarist) and Steve Jones of the Sex Pistols. Danelectro CM-1 Cool Cat Metal: Make sure you get the Cool Cat Metal, NOT Metal II. It's a thin pedal, too, but it's definitely more of a traditional metal pedal. The Cool Cat Metal, or CM-1, is actually a very different pedal to most metal pedals. Basically, it's a pre-amp that sits on the floor. It's got a fully adjustable EQ with tons of volume and gain through the roof. So you can do anything from a clean boost (with gain at least there is virtually no coloring NO to its tone) to gain high metal material, with plenty of big rock tones in the middle. It works well with any amplifier I've tried, and you can find tons of great sounds. It's an incredibly versatile pedal, and its same true bypass. The best part is, Danelectro seems to have done a lot of them, so you can easily find one used or even new to under $30. A real hidden gem that is actually CHEAPER than an DS-1. This little guy surprised me. It's supposed to be an MI Audio Crunch Box clone, and if so, it must be an amazing pedal too. It's essentially a pile of Marshall in a box, and boy he always succeeds at that. Big crush, tons of volume and gain, it really can make your practice amplifier sound like a big pile of rags! Even sounded good going into my modeling amplifier (very few pedals work well with my modeling amplifier, and this even sounded better than the Marshall similarity built in), and you can get a new brand for $40 shipped, fantastic! Speaking of Joyo, I had some pedals as well as one or two of MOEN, another Chinese pedaller, and I'm honestly overwhelmed by how good they sound due to their surprisingly low price tag (especially the MOEN MO-FM Fuzz Mooz Fuzz that honestly outside Big Muffs every Big Muff I've ever touched through). So JOYO and MOEN, both make a variety of large sound felt, od, and ground pedals, check them (and before anyone stands up in arms about supporting a Chinese company, please keep in mind that NONE of the pedals listed in my review, DS-1 included, are made in America, much less the Western hemisphere). I hope these suggestions will give you something to look for. Also, if you can't really try to pedal out in the shop, YouTube is a great place to listen to demos of what different pedals can do. I should also mention that if you try to love DS-1 and it suits your needs, rather than more power for you. Tone is subjective, each pedal sounds different going through different guitars and amplifiers, and s.o. because I can share different opinions about something you love, okay. My main reason for posting this long review is to give new players some information. You have a lot of options for distortion pedals, the DS-1 is not the only thing out there that is accessible. Find something you really love and buy it. If it's the DS-1, one of the pedals I mentioned here, or anything else, the important part is that it sounds right to YOU.

I am very disappointed with the quality and engineering of this product. The solutions to the main problems are after the review. In order of importance, the defects bothering me are: 1) quality: very weak soft metal screws. With minimal force and well aligned drives, all four screw heads I used had some damage. Two of them were rounded too much. I was worried that it would be difficult to remove them in the future, which led me to go to the hardware store to find higher quality replacement screws. 2) Engineering: it is recommended to use in the manual. The screw (the screw provided with straplock) is designed for No. 2 cross screwdriver. However, the standard #2 driver is too large to fit into the belt button. Therefore, you may have to choose between grinding the screwdriver to install or use #1, because this is a wrong tool, which will increase the impact of the first problem above. 3) Project: the connection point of the strap is 5 / 8 inch away from the guitar. The belt button has a radius of approximately 3 / 16 of an inch. Therefore, as the lever pulls the screw outward, any transverse stress (i.e. guitar weight) will be amplified by more than three times. A 9-pound guitar exerts a constant force of 27 to 30 pounds on the screws and the wood around it (of course, half the force when the weight is evenly distributed between the two belt buttons). If you are a little more active on the stage, the level of power may be higher. In fact, if these screws are not nonsense, it may be a three-star or four-star comment. Once you solve the problem of inappropriate ordinary screwdriver and install the screwdriver correctly, it may be suitable for most people. Therefore, if you have been using one set, I suggest you: go to the hardware store to buy #6 x 1 "oval head stainless steel replacement screws. Please note that these screws cannot be installed correctly, but they are the best match and can be modified. (in my local store, each one is 21 cents. Dunlop's batch cost may be 10 cents higher than the garbage screws they bought for this dress.) Put the screw into the electric drill (with the tip facing inward) Therefore, when you operate the drill bit, the screw head can rotate smoothly. Use a file or belt sander to remove a small part of the drill bit diameter from the screw head. This does not require much. I use the belt sander, which takes about 20 seconds at a time. During operation, file down a cheap No. 2 screwdriver to install it into the belt buckle. Installation is the same as ordinary screws Discuss your friends to try different brands!

This is the first guitar slide I bought. I liked it for about a month, and then it fell off my finger and broke into pieces. I almost cut myself! I will never buy a glass slide again. I recently bought a Dunlop brass slide. I like it very much. The difference between glass and metal is that the hue of glass is more turbid and mellow, and the glass is more brittle, louder and will not break. I won't suggest this to anyone. The price of metal is about the same, it won't break, and it sounds better. All professionals use metal for a reason! The following comments are wrong. The slide should cover your whole finger, all the way to the fingertip. You don't bend your fingers on the slide. You reset the guitar to open tuning. I just want to point out that.

Johnson's guitars have a little more action, there aren't too many mountains, and cheaper fitting and finishing. Jasmine's nice, but I haven't spent enough time playing her to give a real review. Yamaha FG700GS is definitely neat to watch, and it has decent dwarves, but it doesn't really have a big shot high to the bottom. It's a little wider down there, so there's more body, but the sound range wasn't generally good. Bristol has great ups and downs in comparison. He was a little fatter on Yahama, too, although with other guitars he looked about the same. I can't help but think the reviews here are a bit of a mind-meld where everyone buys in hype. I may have an incompetent guitar, but I doubt they're all made in the same factory.

Total acoustic sound " well;, But the sound is strange. I gave it back. Compared with the alternatives on the market, its price seems to be high. Advantages - the boss housing is metal, the mechanical design is durable - the standard 9V power supply, and the power socket is located on the back- All kinds of sounds are possible. (personally, I only think one of them sounds realistic) disadvantages - the hissing noise is combined with the playing notes (or chords) - there is usually a little noise in the pedal chain - although I have several boss pedals, I think they always make the knob too small and the font / font too small. I prefer bigger pedals and fewer knobs that can adjust your toes if necessary. Details: the basic concept is good. I have an AC-2 (previous model) and sold it because it has a noise problem. When you play a note, there will be a hissing noise. It's not between notes or when it's not playing, it's combined with the sound of every note (or chord) you play, and you can't filter it. It's also just noise in the pedal chain. Adjusting your guitar volume to a higher gain pickup helps. However, I sold that model because I didn't want to put the pedal with other things, and I was not satisfied with its sound. At that time, the AC-2 sold for about $85. Boss redesigned and significantly increased the price of AC-3. I bought the AC-3 and hoped they could improve the AC-2 problem - they did, a little. But not enough to save it. I returned it a week later because it still had the same basic problems, but it was not so obvious. I think AC-3 can be used as a joke, but there are other options. It sounds like $25 instead of $130 to $150 (including tax and / or freight), so for me, the boss's pedal price is too high and not so good. I chose Bellinger acoustic modeler. They made two --a" 300"  And a" 400".  400 reverberates on the pedal. I chose 300 and spent $25. I expect Bellinger's durability will be lower than that of the boss because it has a plastic shell. However, this is an effect that I occasionally quit because I can buy 4, 5 or 6 bellingers at my boss's price.... If it breaks... I'll buy another one. I also have a boss GT-100 multi effect device. You can get the same or similar acoustically modeled sound from Bellinger or boss AC-3. The least cost-effective of these options is AC-3, which has two other noise problems. I'm not saying it's a bad pedal, I'm just saying that considering the cost, sound and my mode of use, it's not my best choice. If they can solve the noise problem, I can even keep it. I did choose to keep Bellinger because I used discrete pedals and wanted an acoustic model effect. This boss is not so useful to me.

I finally learned my lesson. In the past year or two, I have bought a lot of such things.. Moreover, the previous view is consistent with that of commentators, who believe that it is "suitable for static applications" because the cable conductor is easy to break, even along the cable length, not just at the connector... But they are very cheap, so I think it's no problem. But now, after recently purchasing and installing a cable from the speaker microphone to the digital mixer, I checked it and it seems to work. A week later, a duet began recording, and the microphone cable made the singer sound like singing behind the scenes.. yes.. Cable. So be sure to buy these things at the price, but when you get them.. Please check carefully.. As I have learned, a simple "yes / no" is obviously not good enough

My problem with pedal training 2 is the adjustment of power supply. I have a voodoo lab with 2 + pedal power. The documentation attached to the pedal specifically states that the power supply is installed under the pedal and even includes a mounting bracket suitable for the power supply. However, if you do install it at the bottom of the circuit board as recommended, you will encounter an unpleasant surprise. First, about the two circular holes on the front of the plate. Where is the power supply... To some extent. There is no way to fully align them because the hole in Pedal Train 2 is slightly too close. I am not worried about this because I doubt whether I will chain them and can only visit one store. The second problem is that it is alleged that the self tapping screws attached to the installation tool bar appear to be made of butter. Once you let them in (or try to do so), they'll never come out. You may have to break them. It's a pity to cut corners on such a cheap thing. As for the power supply of my voodoo laboratory, the main problem I encountered on this circuit board is this. Once the power supply is correctly installed at the bottom of the circuit board (only one position can be installed), start inserting the pedal and find that the cable provided by the power supply does not match the installation position on the circuit board. Because there is not enough clearance between the pedal frame and the cable insertion socket, they cannot be inserted. I really only bought this pedal because it has perfect compatibility with my voodoo laboratory power supply, but considering that it does not meet my requirements, I hope I can return this board - except I can't, because it has drilled a hole now. (you must drill holes in the circuit board to install the power supply below it.) Basically, I paid $100 for an ordinary flat metal rectangle and rolls of Velcro fasteners. Needless to say, I'm not very happy.

I bought H4n because I am not satisfied with the performance of H2. Because the performance of H2 is the most important, I cannot record a signal with good sound, and the signal will not be distorted by the line in the jack. It was found that H4n had the same problem, but it was not so bad. If I try to record a line level signal from a soundboard or stereo receiver and connect it to the 1 / 4 inch jack of H4n, it is almost impossible not to produce a distorted signal. On both models, the line in the preamplifier seems to be too sensitive and easy to clip. Because it is clipped in the preamplifier, adjusting the gain does not correct it. I contacted zoom's technical support department about H2 and they told me that there might be a defective device. I returned H2 and decided to give zoom another chance to try H4n after seeing many positive comments. I really like the design of H4n. The menus and controls are well organized. It is stronger than H2. The recording quality using the built-in microphone is very good. Most other recorders in this price range do not have XLR input. Since I plan to use it mainly to record concerts by connecting line output or recording on the soundboard, if the line input jack does not work properly and can not accept the normal line level signal without editing, I can't use it for the purpose of buying it. In the past 8 years, I have used my Sony mini disc recorder for the same type of applications without any problems. I have cooperated with professional audio equipment for more than 25 years and have used many types of recorders. So far, zoom product is the only product I encounter this problem. If you use it to record a microphone, it works well, but if you need to record from a line source, a zoom recorder may not be a good choice. I replaced it with TASCAM dr-07. Although TASCAM doesn't have so many bells and whistles, it is a good recorder. I'm very satisfied with it.

Before I bought FBV, I browsed the Internet to see how it works with pod HD desktop, and even the advanced user's guide makes you think.. Anyway, I was lucky to find a used one cheap. After a while, I fully understood what the combination of pod HD desktop and FBV express II could and could not do. 1. First, in the setup screen, do not enable FBV express. Yes, I know it sounds stupid, but Internet search shows a bug, which is a solution... 2. Read the FBV express user guide and calibrate the pedal.. There is no need to D / l the FBV software for this purpose. Now in the pod setup screen, you can choose to set the ABCD button to ABCD or fs5-fs8. Four switches on the FBV simulate this behavior. Therefore, in ABCD mode, you can: a) select preset a, B, C or D from the current group. b) Insert the volume effect and use the volume pedal... Exp2c) insert another FX enabled by the toe in switch and controlled by the pedal, such as exp1d) click the temperature (by clicking the currently selected preset.. i.e. the illuminated pedal) e) enable the tuner (press and hold the currently selected preset pedal) f) you have some basic control over the looper, but you can't enable it. March 10, 2014 editor: looper control has defects. You can record and go to overdub, but you cannot record and then play / stop the loop.. You can stop from overdub, but you cannot start the loop. This seems to be an admittedly unrepaired error, but if you're like me, switching presets is far less useful than switching FX blocks. By the way, you can combine blocks to make a pedal (for example) turn on OD and turn off delay and chorus at the same time, or turn on an amplifier and turn off an amplifier (channel switching).. yeah!! You cry, it sounds like my voice, so this is a negation of ABCD, mode fs5-fs8, which is for me!.. Therefore, in fs5-8 mode, you can do this. You can a) use four pedals to enable / disable four blocks, b) use the volume and expression options described above (such as volume or Wah, overdrive, delay FB, etc.) C) basic control of looper, but you can't enable itedit 3 / 19 / 14 looper control. There is a defect as described above, c) enable tuner?... Oh, shit. No, you can't) tap the rhythm?.. No, it's not like that. In short, express is better than nothing, but it certainly won't provide hands-free operation on the desktop.. If you read this article before buying pods, the short board is worth it.. Replaced by hd500x.

I bought this brand-new musical instrument on impulse, because I couldn't ignore a manager's selection sale in a local music store. It's brand new, unopened, in a box. They allow me to check it before buying. In that environment, I think it is a good instrument. However, it is difficult to check the instruments correctly in a busy store, and that store is very busy and noisy. Only when you take it home and can check it leisurely in peace will the details stand out. This is really a six string four string piano. Its size is a little over 28 "From top to bottom, there is baritone uke sound. I've heard of sounders and softer instruments in the same price range. Of course, the advantage of this is that it's 6-string, so if you're a guitarist, you can realize the sound and portability of the four string piano without learning new fingering... Of course, until you realize that although it has 6 strings, it's not like Ji He tunes like that. It's tuned to adgcea instead of EADGBE. People can't simply play guitar music with this instrument; all these music must be converted or learn new chord name recognition. As a novice of ukes, this was news to me until I got home and read the manual. So my main purpose of buying this guitar was to buy a small toilet The portable guitar has encountered a problem. Now this is not the end of it all, because you can be a little creative and use different chord lengths to tune it to the standard guitar tuning. This requires a little experiment, but if you don't mind buying several sets of strings and playing a mix, you can set it to the standard guitar tuning. Therefore, nothing is lost here. It's just an example Unexpected surprise - mainly because I didn't study the instrument before buying (I rarely buy on impulse) Therefore, apart from the tuning, we can understand the quality of the instrument. This is the real deficiency of Yamaha. This is an oil, not a paint or shellac finish. In some places, the oil is still visible and can be wiped off by hand. There are several small faults on the finish line out of the box. Obviously, this is an "urgent matter" of a factory , no work at all. No bolts; these need to be added manually (not difficult, but require additional cost and time) Of course, this action is too high. It's not surprising - in fact, it's common in ready-made string instruments, which is not surprising. But in addition to other defects in technology, it is particularly prominent here. However, what bothers me most is: if I don't know this is a Yamaha guitar... I think it's a cheap imitation of a children's guitar. This instrument One place says "quality" - which is very disappointing. This instrument costs about $100. This low cost is obvious. This is a "cheap guitar". To be honest, I can't say it's a toy, but it exudes "beginner's instrument" The tuner is cheap, the surface treatment is cheap, there is no decoration, there is no protective edge. The end point is - not the end point. I bought this completely based on the number of positive comments from Amazon - I respect these comments. People have different tastes, and for some people, it has a kind of "self-control" They'll like it. But I've been playing the guitar for ten years... Uh, I know the difference between quaint and cheap. I have two ovation guitars, a Peavey electric bass, a handmade violin and an Epiphone electric uke (the quality is so high that it's not even a game. No, I'm not Hawking Epiphone. The fact is the fact, that's all. You can read my very positive comments on Epiphone on Amazon). When I got home and looked carefully, I found that there was no sign of quality or workmanship, and there was nothing like "it was made by manpower as cheap and fast as possible" More telling. In fact, the only positive thing I want to say is that it does have a spruce top, and the quality of the strings is quite good. In addition to these two factors, a full-size guitar for $40-50 can be found everywhere in Amazon, which is equivalent to or better than this instrument. The only benefit this will provide is its smaller size and the sound of the four string piano Sound - if someone especially wants a cheap portable guitar tuned like a four string piano. In addition to its portability, I find it has no special advantages, even if its price is relatively low... Consider its pricing (or, more specifically, in manufacturing) People must admit that this is largely a matter of personal taste and expectations. But low quality is low quality. (editor in two weeks: I saw Cordoba in a local store today - it's a direct competitor of the instrument. Cordoba is more beautiful. It's better built, better sound and better finished products. I'm sorry, Yamaha, but the fact is the fact. If I see Cordoba and Yamaha appear side by side, I'll buy and keep Cordoba.) This is my honest comment. I know some people will disagree. But others fully understand what I mean. This is not an expensive instrument, so people really can't expect super high quality at this price. However, I paid almost the same price for my electric uke, which is of first-class quality from top to bottom. As mentioned earlier, Cordoba is a better one Fortunately, the local businessmen have a satisfactory guarantee that I can return it. Unless there is no better choice - frankly, there is a better choice, I can't recommend this tool.

I bought this brand-new musical instrument on impulse, because I couldn't ignore a manager's selection sale in a local music store. It's brand new, unopened, in a box. They allow me to check it before buying. In that environment, I think it is a good instrument. However, it is difficult to check the instruments correctly in a busy store, and that store is very busy and noisy. Only when you take it home and can check it leisurely in peace will the details stand out. This is really a six string four string piano. Its size is a little over 28 "From top to bottom, there is baritone uke sound. I've heard of sounders and softer instruments in the same price range. Of course, the advantage of this is that it's 6-string, so if you're a guitarist, you can realize the sound and portability of the four string piano without learning new fingering... Of course, until you realize that although it has 6 strings, it's not like Ji He tunes like that. It's tuned to adgcea instead of EADGBE. People can't simply play guitar music with this instrument; all these music must be converted or learn new chord name recognition. As a novice of ukes, this was news to me until I got home and read the manual. So my main purpose of buying this guitar was to buy a small toilet The portable guitar has encountered a problem. Now this is not the end of it all, because you can be a little creative and use different chord lengths to tune it to the standard guitar tuning. This requires a little experiment, but if you don't mind buying several sets of strings and playing a mix, you can set it to the standard guitar tuning. Therefore, nothing is lost here. It's just an example Unexpected surprise - mainly because I didn't study the instrument before buying (I rarely buy on impulse) Therefore, apart from the tuning, we can understand the quality of the instrument. This is the real deficiency of Yamaha. This is an oil, not a paint or shellac finish. In some places, the oil is still visible and can be wiped off by hand. There are several small faults on the finish line out of the box. Obviously, this is an "urgent matter" of a factory , no work at all. No bolts; these need to be added manually (not difficult, but require additional cost and time) Of course, this action is too high. It's not surprising - in fact, it's common in ready-made string instruments, which is not surprising. But in addition to other defects in technology, it is particularly prominent here. However, what bothers me most is: if I don't know this is a Yamaha guitar... I think it's a cheap imitation of a children's guitar. This instrument One place says "quality" - which is very disappointing. This instrument costs about $100. This low cost is obvious. This is a "cheap guitar". To be honest, I can't say it's a toy, but it exudes "beginner's instrument" The tuner is cheap, the surface treatment is cheap, there is no decoration, there is no protective edge. The end point is - not the end point. I bought this completely based on the number of positive comments from Amazon - I respect these comments. People have different tastes, and for some people, it has a kind of "self-control" They'll like it. But I've been playing the guitar for ten years... Uh, I know the difference between quaint and cheap. I have two ovation guitars, a Peavey electric bass, a handmade violin and an Epiphone electric uke (the quality is so high that it's not even a game. No, I'm not Hawking Epiphone. The fact is the fact, that's all. You can read my very positive comments on Epiphone on Amazon). When I got home and looked carefully, I found that there was no sign of quality or workmanship, and there was nothing like "it was made by manpower as cheap and fast as possible" More telling. In fact, the only positive thing I want to say is that it does have a spruce top, and the quality of the strings is quite good. In addition to these two factors, a full-size guitar for $40-50 can be found everywhere in Amazon, which is equivalent to or better than this instrument. The only benefit this will provide is its smaller size and the sound of the four string piano Sound - if someone especially wants a cheap portable guitar tuned like a four string piano. In addition to its portability, I find it has no special advantages, even if its price is relatively low... Consider its pricing (or, more specifically, in manufacturing) People must admit that this is largely a matter of personal taste and expectations. But low quality is low quality. (editor in two weeks: I saw Cordoba in a local store today - it's a direct competitor of the instrument. Cordoba is more beautiful. It's better built, better sound and better finished products. I'm sorry, Yamaha, but the fact is the fact. If I see Cordoba and Yamaha appear side by side, I'll buy and keep Cordoba.) This is my honest comment. I know some people will disagree. But others fully understand what I mean. This is not an expensive instrument, so people really can't expect super high quality at this price. However, I paid almost the same price for my electric uke, which is of first-class quality from top to bottom. As mentioned earlier, Cordoba is a better one Fortunately, the local businessmen have a satisfactory guarantee that I can return it. Unless there is no better choice - frankly, there is a better choice, I can't recommend this tool.

They let me examine it before I bought it. In this environment, I thought it was a nice instrument. However, it may be difficult to properly examine the instrument in a crowded shop, and this shop was very busy and noisy with plums. When you get home and you can calmly and calmly examine the details that stand out. It's a really 6-string ukulele. It's a little over 28. "from top to bottom and has the sound of baritone uke. I've heard of the same instruments at the same price. The advantage of this, of course, is that it is a 6-string, so if you are a guitar player you can achieve ukulele sound and portability without learning a completely new finger.... Of course, until you realize he's got six strings, he's not wired like a guitar. Designed for ADGCEA, not EADGBE. You can't just play that instrument. such music must be transposed or learn to recognize a new accordion name. As a rookie in ukes, it was news to me until I got home and read the instructions. So my main goal in buying this... have a small portable guitar, hit an obstacle. It's not over yet, because you can be a little creative and use alternate string sizes to customize it to the standard guitar customization. You need to experiment a little, but it is possible to set it to standard guitar tuning if you don't mind buying a few strings and playing a mix. So not everything is lost. It was just an unexpected surprise, mainly because I didn't study the instrument before the purchase (I rarely buy impulsive). So, without adjusting, we come to the quality of the instrument. That's where Yamaha really falls apart. It is oil rather than varnish or shellac and in several places oil would still be visible and could be manually wiped. There were a few faults in the finish, straight from the box. Yeah. The fact that it was a "quick job" from a factory without a finished job was obvious. There are no tape clips; they will require adding manually (not difficult, but additional costs and time). The action is obviously too high. It's not unusual. In fact, this is quite common in secondary string instruments and was not surprising. But along with other mistakes in her performance, she stood here. But what worries me most is that if I wasn't aware that it was Yamaha's guitar... I think it's a cheap guitar for kids. There is not one thing in this instrument that says'quality', which is disappointing. This instrument is sold for about a hundred. This low price is obvious. It's a cheap guitar in every way. I can't honestly say it's a toy, but it smells like a beginner's instrument. Tunnels are as cheap as they come, finishing is cheap, there is no decoration, there are no protective edges. The end is... unfinished. I only bought it based on the number of positive reviews in the Amazon, and I respect those reviews. People have different tastes and for some people it has a "home made" feeling that they will love. But I played guitar for... Dean. Uh-huh. And I know the difference between peculiar and cheap. I own two Ovation guitars, Peavey bass electric, hand-made violins and Epiphone electric uke (which is so high quality that it's not even a competition. And I'm not Hawking Epifone. Facts are facts, that's all. You can read my very positive review in Epiphone on the Amazon). When I got home and took a good look at it, I found no traces of quality or craftsmanship, nothing that said more than "it was done as cheaply and as quickly as possible." In fact, the only positive thing I have to say about it is that it has a side of the cricket, and the strings have a pretty decent quality. In addition to these two factors, you can find $40$50 full-size guitars throughout the Amazon that are equal to or superior to this instrument in quality. The only advantage it offers is its smaller size and ukulele voice-- if anyone particularly wants a cheap, portable guitar tuned like uke. Apart from its portability, I see no special value in it, and even at a relatively low price... consider it excessive (or rather immature) price. You have to admit, it's a matter of personal taste and expectations. But the quality is low. (Edition two weeks later: Italy dream today I s a w Cordoba in a local shop-- direct competition to this instrument. Cordoba i s much nicer. It is built better, has better sound, and is finished much more pleasantly. I'm sorry Yamaha, but the facts with her facts. If I saw Cordoba and Yamaha next to each other, buy I stopped Cordoba.) I like TASCAM gear, which has been used for nearly 30 years. I'm happy to try this interface and see what it can do. Unfortunately, I'm disappointed. Although the structure and mechanical function of the device itself are good, there are still many deficiencies in the actual function of the computer. In addition, I got no manuals at all, which makes it difficult for me to understand these functions. (I'm sorry, but for such an expensive device with 2 software CDs, how difficult is it to include the complete manual on the installation CD?) It contains a very small quick start guide, which basically names the various switches, inputs and outputs, and gives very sparse instructions for using the software mixer screen. I was forced to experiment to see if I could record serious recordings in any remote way similar to multi track mode. I can't. I can record and layer multiple tracks (I was using audacity and didn't want to install Cubase), but I can't play from previous tracks, and I have real-time input. Now, this may be my computer or audacity, because it is an older Win XP machine, but it can play multiple tracks without problem. There is nothing in the mini Quick Start Guide to illustrate this, not even any hint, except to visit TASCAM's website. I'm sorry, but it's not good enough for such expensive equipment. There should be a complete manual, at least in PDF format, included in the product. If I'm going to use it for serious recording, the last thing I want to do is waste a lot of time mining information from the website, or worse, from the "user community" threads of some blogs. This leads to another small problem - there is no linux driver. I mainly use Linux. Only one windows machine can run software that Linux cannot run. I want to try the software under wine on Linux, but time is limited. Then there is the general problem of software interface replacing hardware. With the hardware mixer, I can access as many controls as my fingers can handle at the same time (three or four on some mixers). Computerized mixers can only do one thing at a time and must constantly move the cursor from one thing to another to access control. The controls on this interface are very complex. You must accurately position the cursor on a small part of the button to make it react. I found it very boring, and again, there are no practical instructions to help the process. It might be easier with a touch screen, but in that case, why not use buttons on a real mixer? (yes, I know. The touch screen is cool.) In addition, software based functionality is always limited by computers and operating systems, which means that everyone has a different experience - consistency is more difficult to maintain. I'm an old school person. I find the hardware mixer more sensitive and useful. I know many people are excited about installing software versions of hardware and saving space on their computers. However, I value function rather than fashion. This is my favorite TASCAM gear: it has excellent function. This software is far from meeting my expectations of TASCAM, and the lack of interface manual is unforgivable. Good mixers, especially for multichannel recording, may be complex and difficult to learn. The layers of signal interconnection may be difficult to understand at first and take some time to adapt. The old TASCAM manual actually has some guidance on multi track recording, which is very helpful for aspiring recording artists. This is not the case here. I really want to give this 3 or 4 stars, but unfortunately, it only gives me a score of 2 (2.5, if I can). Come on, Tuscan, you can do better.

As far as I know, the angle of the guitar is about 40 to 45 degrees. It looks silly, like your guitar is trying to slide out of the shelf or fall back in slow motion. I eventually returned these booths, but if they were made in a more upright version, I would definitely buy them again.

TASCAM th-2000 headphones are like a pair of studio monitors on your ears! They're great! Excellent bass response (not muddy at all), compact midrange and clear treble. From the boots, they are also very comfortable. The foam fits your ears very well, and it fits the outline of your face. They are adjustable, so if you have a huge head, you can still wear these. The only drawback I can see, I don't even think it's negative, is the curly rope. Some people may not like it. All these are great headphones - I've listened to all kinds of music with them, monitored recordings with them, and so on... Outstanding by the way, they are also very good at eliminating foreign noise in the background and making the music clearer. It's great that taskam has made such good headphones! Updated May 12, 2014 - these headphones stop working after several months of normal operation. I have a cheap Bellinger couple who have experienced more abuse and are still working. How disappointing!!!
